overview: Apply for a Gender Recognition Certificate to legally change your gender
title: Applying for a Gender Recognition Certificate

table.body:
By law you remain your birth gender unless you apply for a Gender Recognition Certificate to change it legally. To do this you must:

- be 18 or over
- have lived as your new gender for 2 years (or changed gender legally abroad)
- apply to the Gender Recognition Panel 

##Pensions
UK law sometimes treats men and women differently, eg women can claim the State Pension earlier. Changing your gender could affect your company or personal pension schemes. 

$D
[Download Guidance on benefits and pensions (PDF, 192KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/gender-recognition-panel/other-guidance-and-information/GuideBenefitsPension.pdf "Guidance on benefits and pensions, PDF, 192KB")
$D

##Marriages and civil partnerships
If you legally change your gender you'll need to dissolve your marriage or civil partnership.

$D
[Download Guidance for married people or those in civil partnerships (PDF, 150kb)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/gender-recognition-panel/other-guidance-and-information/GuideMarriedCivil10052011.pdf "Guidance for married people or those in civil partnerships, PDF, 150kb")
$D

^You have [legal rights](http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/advice-and-guidance/your-rights/transgender/ "Legal rights as a transgender person"){:rel="external"} as a transgender person.^
table.title: Overview

table.body:
Fill out the application form and check your fee (maximum £140).
 
$D
[Download Gender Recognition Certificate application form (PDF, 57KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/ts-grp/gender-recognition-applicationf-form-gender-recognition-certificate.pdf "Gender Recognition Certificate application form, PDF, 57KB")

[Download help with the application form (PDF, 221KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/ts-grp/guidance-completing-applic-gender-recognition-certificate.pdf "Help notes for the Gender Recognition Certificate application form, PDF, 221KB") 

[Download application fees (PDF, 150KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/gender-recognition-panel/other-guidance-and-information/fees_applyingtoGRP10052011.pdf "Application fees, PDF, 150KB") 
$D
 
Send the form with the application fee to the Gender Recognition Panel: 

$A 
Gender Recognition Panel  
PO Box 9300  
Leicester  
LE1 8DJ  
$A

##If you've changed your gender abroad
If you legally changed your gender in the European Union (EU) or the European Economic Area (EEA), this is recognised in the UK.

If the country you changed it in is an 'approved country' outside the EU or EEA (check the list below), it's partially recognised in the UK but you'll need to re-apply using a simplified process. 

If the country isn't approved, you'll need to follow the full application process using the standard form above.

*[EU]: European Union
*[EEA]: European Economic Area

$D
[List of approved countries, (PDF, 147KB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/gender-recognition-panel/list-of-approved-countries-or-territories/table_of_gender_recognition_schemes_apr_2004.pdf "List of approved countries where the UK recognises a gender change, PDF, 147KB")
[Overseas application form, (PDF, 1.1MB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/ts-grp/applicationfor-overseas-GRC16052011.pdf "Overseas application form, PDF, 1.1MB")
[Help with the overseas application form (PDF, 1.1MB)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/global/forms/tribunals/ts-grp/guidanceformforGRC-10052011.pdf "Help with the overseas application form, PDF, 1.1MB")
$D

##How the Gender Recognition Panel decides

s1. The panel may ask you for more information or evidence, eg medical reports.
s2. If you're successful, the panel will send you a Gender Recognition Certificate (proof of your legal gender change). 
s4. The panel will send you a new short birth certificate (listing name, sex, date of birth, district and sub-district of birth) - you can apply for and pay for a full one.
s5. If you're unsuccessful, the panel will write to you with their reasons.
s6. You have the right to appeal - the panel will explain how.
table.title: Applying to the Gender Recognition Panel

table.body:
##Certificates
You’ll need to change your birth certificate and other documents that mention your gender. 

You’ll get a free ‘short’ birth certificate (listing name, sex, date of birth, district and sub-district of birth) if your birth was registered in the UK. You can apply for and pay for a full one.
 
%You'll need to tell certain government departments about your gender change - the Gender Recognition Panel will tell you which ones.%

##Marriages and civil partnerships
You'll get an interim Gender Recognition Certificate if you're married or in a civil partnership so you can easily end it.

You'll then get a full Gender Recognition Certificate so you can marry or partner the other person depending on their legal gender.

$D
[Download Guidance for married people or those in civil partnerships (PDF, 150kb)](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/guidance/courts-and-tribunals/tribunals/gender-recognition-panel/other-guidance-and-information/GuideMarriedCivil10052011.pdf "Guidance for married people or those in civil partnerships, PDF, 150kb")
$D

##Wills
If you’re named in a will as your birth gender, eg ‘my eldest son’ or ‘my daughter’, get [expert help from a solicitor](# "Find a legal adviser"). You can ask a court to look at the will, taking the Gender Recognition Act into account.

^Your children are not legally affected by your legal gender change - you’re still their mother or father as stated on their birth certificate.^
table.title: Legal documents following a gender change
